item.title: One Boston Bombing Suspect Is Dead, Second at Large; Area on Lockdown
item.description: One suspect in Monday’s marathon bombings was killed in a standoff with the police in Watertown, Mass. A manhunt is under way for the second suspect.
item.dc:creator: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE and MICHAEL COOPER
item.media:credit: Eric Thayer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Authorities are focusing on an area of Norfolk Street.

item.title: Assailants Gun Down Syrian Official
item.description: A squad of assailants using shot to death a government official in a gangland-style killing as he dined in the upscale Mezzeh district of the Syrian capital, residents and activists said.
item.dc:creator: By HWAIDA SAAD and ALAN COWELL

item.title: African Islamists Free French Captives
item.description: A French family held hostage for two months by Islamist militants in West Africa has been released, French and Cameroonian officials announced on Friday.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE

item.title: Pervez Musharraf Arrested in Pakistan
item.description: A judge placed Pakistan’s former military leader, Pervez Musharraf, under arrest Friday, as the country’s judiciary pursued its drive to hold him accountable for his actions during his nine years in power.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Greeks Held in Shooting of Migrant Workers
item.description: Three foremen of a strawberry farm in southern Greece accused of wounding 28 Bangladeshi workers over unpaid wages were arrested on Friday, police officials said.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: China’s North Korea Envoy to Visit Washington
item.description: The visit comes after Secretary of State John Kerry said in Beijing last week that China could play a vital role in helping rid North Korea of its nuclear weapons.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Britain Accuses GlaxoSmithKline of Conspiring With Rivals
item.description: The antitrust authorities accused GlaxoSmithKline of paying three rivals to delay the introduction of a generic version of an anti-depressant drug.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: British Police Arrest Entertainer in Abuse Inquiry
item.description: The British media identified Rolf Harris, a singer and artist, as the newest high-profile arrest after the Jimmy Savile affair.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: 1 Marathon Suspect Arrested After Violent Standoff With Police
item.description: One suspect in Monday’s marathon bombings was killed in a standoff with police in Watertown, Mass. A manhunt is under way for a man who was identified by the F.B.I. as a suspect earlier in the day.
item.dc:creator: By RAVI SOMAIYA
item.media:description: The Boston Police Department released this image of the suspect at large on Friday.

item.title: Warsaw Journal: Poland Reconnects to Jewish Past With Museum
item.description: Among civic leaders in Warsaw, a new Jewish museum is seen as a major step toward recognizing Poland’s Jewish past and recovering from its 20th-century traumas.
item.category: Museum of the History of Polish Jews
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:credit: Piotr Malecki for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wladyslaw Bartoszewski, an Auschwitz survivor, right, at the new Jewish museum in Warsaw.

item.title: The Lede: Officer Shot and Killed on M.I.T. Campus
item.description: A Massachusetts Institute of Technology campus police officer was shot and killed near the campus in Cambridge, Mass.,Thursday night, authorities said.
item.dc:creator: By RAVI SOMAIYA
item.media:description: Police officers blocked off the scene of a shooting at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge, Mass.

item.title: M.I.T. Police Officer Dies After Shooting, Authorities Say
item.description: A police officer for the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has been shot and killed at the campus outside of Boston, authorities said early Friday. No arrests had been made and a manhunt was on for the shooter.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Facing Arrest, Musharraf Flees Pakistani Courtroom
item.description: The police escorted Pervez Musharraf, the country’s former military leader, back to court a day after his dramatic escape when a judge revoked his bail.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: The convoy carrying Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan’s former leader, left the court on Thursday.

item.title: F.A.A. Expected to Approve 787 Dreamliner Fix
item.description: The decision by the Federal Aviation Administration would allow the planes, grounded for more than three months, to return to service after the proposed repairs are made.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER DREW

item.title: The Lede: Nurses Sought in Beatings at Russian Orphanage
item.description: Three residents of an orphanage, the oldest just 3 years old, were severely injured, drawing new attention to the plight of orphans in Russia.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ

item.title: After Gun Bill Defeat, Reid Calls for ‘Pause’
item.description: The failure this week of the Senate’s search for consensus on gun control after the Newtown shooting can be traced to timing, convoluted rules and a counterproductive alliance.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER
item.media:description: On Monday, relatives of some of the Connecticut massacre victims arrived at Andrews Air Force Base with President Obama.

item.title: News Analysis: After Apple’s Rise, a Bruising Fall
item.description: Shares of Apple were trading for more than $700 last year, but they have tumbled back and analysts are trying to understand why.
item.dc:creator: By NATHANIEL POPPER and NICK WINGFIELD
item.media:description: An iPad, left, with an iPad Mini. Apple enjoys robust sales and is expanding around the world, but its stock price is declining.

item.title: U.S. Selling Arms to Israel, Saudi Arabia and Emirates
item.description: A $10 billion deal would provide missiles, warplanes and troop transports to help Israel, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates counter threats from Iran.
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER
item.media:description: Chuck Hagel on Thursday before a meeting with Ban Ki-moon of the United Nations.

item.title: Suspect Denies Mailing Poisoned Letter to Obama
item.description: Paul Kevin Curtis, charged with sending letters believed to bear ricin, was surprised by his arrest, his lawyer said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Huge Blast at Texas Fertilizer Plant Kills at Least 5
item.description: A day after a blast in West, Tex., so powerful it registered as an earthquake, the cause was unclear but the effects — as many as 15 dead, up to 180 hurt and much of a town gone — were plain.
item.dc:creator: By MANNY FERNANDEZ and JOHN SCHWARTZ
item.media:description: Emergency personnel conducting a search on Thursday of an apartment complex destroyed by an explosion the day before at a fertilizer plant in West, Tex.

item.title: F.B.I. Seeks Public Aid in Finding Two Men Suspected in Bombings
item.description: In a direct appeal for help from the public, the F.B.I. released pictures and video of two young men officials believe may be behind the deadly explosions during the Boston Marathon.
item.dc:creator: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE, MICHAEL COOPER and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.media:description: An image released on Thursday by the F.B.I. shows one of the suspects wanted for questioning.

item.title: New Chemical Weapons Allegations in Syria Conflict
item.description: Britain and France have informed the United Nations that there is credible information suggesting that Syria’s government has used chemical weapons in the civil war, diplomats said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
International Committee of the Red Cross
United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: After Airstrike, Afghan Points to C.I.A. and Secret Militias
item.description: In critical remarks, a spokesman for the Afghan president said that an airstrike in which 12 children were killed was part of a C.I.A.-run operation.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: The graves of some children killed in an airstrike in Kunar Province, in eastern Afghanistan, this month.

item.title: Monetary Fund Chief Warns Against ‘3-Speed’ Recovery
item.description: Christine Lagarde, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, instead called for developing nations, the United States and Europe to move to a “full-speed” economy.
item.dc:creator: By ANNIE LOWREY
item.media:description: Christine Lagarde at the opening of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund's spring meetings in Washington this week.

item.title: 2 Good Places to Live, 1,200 Light-Years Away
item.description: “One thing is clear, deluding ourselves that our patch of blue is unique doesn’t seem to be helping us take care of it,” writes Wendyloch.
